text: Family Member: Okay. Doctor: You can’t actually see the lymph nodes when you remove them, you just see packets of fat. Family Member: Oh. Doctor: So we always go to the same area so we remove these packets of fat from that area along the pelvic side wall, it’s along the iliac arteries. Family Member: Mm, hmm. (pause) Doctor: Yes. text: Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And there’s actually a group that would get you back to California. There’s a group at UCLA (laughs) Patient: And how does, what’s the effect of that when you get treated? I mean what is, what’s different about that? Would that, would that go after the growth in the lymph nodes? Doctor: Yes. So PSMA is a thing that’s on the surface of crossing cancer cells. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: And it’s an enzyme, which means uh we’re not really sure what it does but we are, we’re able to block its function with a with a small drug. Uh and what people actually here when we started doing it, uh people thought well that would be cool to take an image of the cancer- Patient: Yeah. Doctor: which will see where it is. So we put a little radioactive tag- Patient: Okay. Doctor: and the only PSMA does is go from the surface inside the cancer cell, and it’s almost, it’s almost a way to build something up inside. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So we can get a really nice picture. Well, the next easy lead from there is why not put something that’s a killer mode. Uh what they’ve seen, and what’s been published in the German, mostly Germany, it’s relatively nontoxic. Uh the big toxicity has been uh the salivary glands seem to make PSMA also. So some people end up with dry mouth uh as a side effect. Uh the kidney also makes P- PSMA. They haven’t really reported acute kidney damage, hasn’t really been a big issue, but they haven’t really followed the people long enough I think to know-

text: Patient: Um hum. Doctor: - to go to humans, human trials, but, uh, unless, unless your pain is getting substantially worse, in which case I would strongly encourage you to do the chemo, because that’s going to work the fastest. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Unless the pain is clearly getting worse, and if I feel that we have like a window of opportunity, where, you know, maybe the hasn’t worked but your cancer is not bad enough that you need chemotherapy right this second, then that might be like an opportunity to try a second trial. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: But if I truly believe that this pain is escalating or you’re having, you know, more bad days than good days, or, you know, you’re really not able to sleep for more than like an hour at a time because you’re waking up because of back pain, those types of things would certainly lead me towards maybe chemotherapy as the next step, and perhaps reserving that clinical trial for after the chemotherapy is over. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Because that also would be a possibility, i.e., come off the trial, do some chemotherapy with the K___ oncologist, and then on the back end, when the chemotherapy is over, come back and do a different clinical trial at that point. Patient: Um hum. Okay. Okay. Okay. And, again, that’s one of the reasons why I wanted to come here, uh, uh, from the um perspective of the options. And, uh, and I, I, maybe I shouldn’t say this because your recorder is here, but I do like, not only the professionalism here, but, I, I like the sense of, uh, caring that the personnel here, uh, express. That’s from everybody within the building when you, when you come in. But the other thing is, when I come here to get lab work done, uh, I only get stuck one time. You know? I don’t like to be a big pincushion and you’ve gotten stuck four or five times, and the person still hasn’t hit the vein. Can I try your other arm? And I’m thinking like, come on, now. This, this reminds me of the time when I was in the Marine Corp. The corpsman do the stuff on purpose. You know? Doctor: Okay. Patient: So it is what it is. But I said that to say the quality of care and the compassion I can see here at J___ H___. I’m not saying it’s not there at K___. There’s some good doctors there, good personnel, that have been very helpful to me. Uh, but, uh, I see it all through the building here when I come here. That’s one thing. I could see it. Doctor: So are we all on the same page now?

text: Patient: There is? Doctor: There is. Yeah, yeah, there's one I think that's purple and I'm pretty sure there's a blue one. Again, I peruse the poop in the mouth aisle, because I don't like to recommend things that you can't get access to. You know, when it sounds good on paper and in the textbooks, and then you go to Meijer, you go to Rite Aid and you're like, “what are you talking about, I've never seen it”. So I will peruse the same store as you guys shop at because if I don't see it then how are you going to play it? So I do know Crest has one that says no alcohol that's a blue and I'm pretty sure Listerine is purple that's a no alcohol, so those are two really good ones. You know I’d still cut it a little bit with the water. Family Member 1: What about toothpaste? Doctor: Same with a lot of the whitening and all that is very harsh on the gums. You know there's Sensodyne, which is very calming. Family Member 1: I have to do a prescription because Doctor: Oh, okay. Family Member 1: Well I’m on blood thinners every day. Patient: So M___ is the next person to come in? Doctor: M____'s coming right in. Family Member 2: Can I ask you a question? Doctor: Yeah. Family Member 2: So he has taken some Ambien once in a while to sleep, is that okay or no?

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
